help.helpText: Implements the boolean AND operation: outputs 1 if both inputs equal 1, otherwise outputs 0.
This module represents a constant boolean value i.e. true|false, that can be connected to any boolean input. The input will have that value during the whole execution.
Converts `false` to `0` and `true` to `1`.
Outputs 1 if the inputs are equal within the specified tolerance, that is, if abs(A-B) ≤ tolerance. Otherwise outputs 0.
Outputs 1 if A is greater than B (A>B). If equality is set to true, outputs 1 if A≥B. Otherwise outputs 0.
If the value at the if input is 1, then outputs the value present at the then input. Otherwise outputs the value at else input.
Outputs 1 if A is less than B (A<B). If equality is set to true, outputs 1 if A≤B. Otherwise outputs 0.
Implements the boolean NOT operation: outputs 0 if the input equals 1, otherwise outputs 1.
Implements the boolean OR operation: outputs 1 if at least one of the inputs equal 1, otherwise outputs 0.
Outputs 0 unless both inputs have the same sign. If both inputs are positive, the output is 1. If both are negative, the output is -1.
Implements the boolean XOR operation: outputs true if one of the inputs equal true, otherwise outputs false.

This module allows you to implement custom functionality by writing code in the Java programming language directly in your browser.

Click the Edit code button to open the code editor. The code you write will be dynamically compiled and executed.

See the User Guide for more information on programmable modules.

params.buttonName: The name which the button gets
params.outputValue: Value which is outputted when the button is clicked

help.helpText: The button module outputs the given value everytime the button is pressed. Module can be used any time, even during a run.
The module ouputs even 1 or 0 depending of the value of the switcher. The value can be changed during a run.
The module outputs the value of the text field every time 'send' is pressed.

This module sends inputs as HTTP request to given URL, and returns server response. Headers, query params and body should be Maps. Body can also be List or String. Request body format can be changed in Options. Default is JSON. Server is expected to return JSON formatted documents. HTTP Request is asynchronous by default. Synchronized requests block the execution of the whole canvas until they receive the server response, but otherwise they work just like any other module; asynchronous requests on the other hand work like streams in that they activate modules they're connected to only when they receive data from the server. If a data path branches, and one branch passes through the HTTP Request module and another around it, if they also converge in a module, that latter module may experience multiple activations due to asynchronicity. This also means that server responses may arrive in different order than they were sent. If this kind of behaviour causes problems, you can try to fix it by changing sync mode to synchronized in Options. However, data throughput WILL be lower, and external servers may freeze your canvas simply by responding very slowly or not at all. For simple data paths and somewhat stable response times, the two sync modes will yield precisely the same results.

params.URL: URL of MQTT broker to listen to

help.helpText:
Listen to MQTT messages, output them as strings. If message is JSON, a JsonParser module can be used to transform the string into a map, and GetMultiFromMap module to extract values from the map.

Examples:

Connecting to MQTT service without certificate

Give URL address as

mqtt://service.com

or

tcp://service.com

Add topic and username and password if needed.

Connecting to MQTT with certificate

Give URL address as

ssl://service.com

Add topic and username and password if needed.

Select certificate type to be .crt and paste your certificate to text area.
There is no documentation for this module at this time.
help.message: Non-authenticated user does not have permission to read ModulePackage (id 5)

outputs.result: List of rows returned by the database

help.helpText: The result is a list of map objects, e.g. [{"id":0, "name":"Me"}, {"id":1, "name":"You"}]
BinaryBetting Ethereum contract

params.ethAccount: The account used to make transaction or call

inputs.trigger: Send call (for functions that have no inputs)
inputs.ether: ETH to send with the function call (for payable functions)

help.helpText:
Call Ethereum smart contract.

First, connect Ethereum contract into contract input. You can write your own using SolidityModule, or pick a template such as PayByUse.

Second, choose the function you want to call from the dropdown. There are two kinds of functions calls:

  • constant function calls that return results directly, and
  • transactions that return values through events that the function call invokes.

The contract must be deployed before this module can activate.
Ethereum contract that has been deployed in the blockchain
Get events sent out by given contract in the given transaction
PayByUse Ethereum contract

params.ethAccount: The account used to deploy contract
params.initial ETH: initial ETH amount to be deployed with contract

help.helpText: Compile and deploy Ethereum smart contract. Edit the code in text window, close window and then contract will be compiled. Enter constructor args and initial ETH (if applicable) and press deploy. Deployed address will be displayed in bottom text field. You can connect the contract output to SendEthereumTransaction module.
Given message and signature get Ethereum address of signee.

params.index: index to add to, from 0 to length of list

outputs.error: error string if given invalid index

help.helpText: Insert an item into an arbitrary position of a List. Unless adding to the very end of a list, items starting from index are all shifted to the right to allow insertion of new item.
Append an item to the end of a List.
Build a fixed-sized list from values at inputs.
This module allows you to manually enter a constant List object.
Checks whether a list contains an item.

Flattens lists inside a list, e.g. [1, [2,3], [4, 5], 6, [7, 8], 9] -> [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9].

 

If deep = true, flattening will be done recursively. E.g. [1, [2, [3, [4, 5, [6]]], 7], 8, 9] -> [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. Otherwise only one level of flattening will be perfomed.

params.keepState: when false, sub-canvas state is cleared after lists have been processed

outputs.numOfItems: indicates how many times the sub-canvas was executed

help.helpText:
Execute a sub-canvas for each item of input lists.

 

The exported inputs and outputs of sub-canvas canvas appear as list inputs and list outputs. The input lists are iterated element-wise, and the sub-canvas is executed every time a value is available for each input list. If input list sizes vary, the sub-canvas is executed as many times as the smallest list is of size. After the input lists have been iterated through, and the sub-canvas activated accordingly, lists of produced values are sent to output lists.

 

The output numOfItems indicates how many times the sub-canvas was executed, i.e., the size of the smallest input list.

 

You may want to look into the module RepeatItem when using this module to repeat parameter values etc.

params.index: Index in the list for the item to be fetched. Negative index counts from end of list.

help.helpText:
Fetch item from a list by index.

Indexing starts from zero, so the first item has index 0, second has index 1 etc.

Negative index counts from end of list, so that last item in the list has index -1, second-to-last has index -2 etc.

params.limit: the maximum number of items to include

outputs.out: a list containing the first items of a list

help.helpText: Retrieves the first (a maximum of limit) items of a list.

outputs.indexes: list of indexes of occurrences; empty list if none

help.helpText: Finds indexes of all occurrences of an item in a list.

outputs.index: outputs the index of the first occurrence; does not output anything if no occurrences

help.helpText: Finds the index of the first occurrence of an item in a list.

outputs.indices: a list of indices for the input list

help.helpText: Generates a list from [0,n-1] according to the size n of the given input list.
Determine size of list.

outputs.item: input list items one by one as separate events

help.helpText:
Split input list into separate events. They will be sent out as separate events, one item at a time.

Each event causes activation of all modules where the output item is sent to.

inputs.head: the first items of the merged list
inputs.tail: the last items of the merged list

help.helpText: Merge two lists (head + tail) together to form a singe list. Merging is simply done by adding items of tail to the end of head to form a single list.

params.from: start of sequence; included in sequence.
params.step: step size to add/subtract; sign is ignored; an empty sequence is produced if set to 0
params.to: upper bound of sequence; not necessarily included in sequence

help.helpText:
Generates a sequence of numbers increasing/decreasing according to a specified step.

 

When from < to a growing sequence is produced. Otherwise (from > to) a decreasing sequence is produced. The sign of parameter step is ignored, and is automatically determined by the inequality relation between from and to.

 

Parameter to acts as an upper bound which means that if sequence generation goes over to, the exceeding values are not included in the sequence. E.g., from=1, to=2, seq=0.3 results in [1, 1.3, 1.6, 1.9], with 2.1 notably not included.

outputs.out: the list with the item removed

help.helpText: Remove an item from a list by index. Given an invalid index, this module simply outputs the original input list.
Make a list out of an item by repeating it times times.
Reverses a list.
Shuffle the items of a list.
Sort a list.

outputs.error: error string in case error occurred

help.helpText:
Extract a sub list from a list.

 

This module is strict about correct indexing. If given incorrect indices, instead of a sub list being produced, an error will be produced in output error.

params.limit: the maximum number of items to include

outputs.out: a list containing the last items of a list

help.helpText: Retrieves the last (a maximum of limit) items of a list.
Removes duplicate items from a list resulting in a list of unique items. The first occurrence of an item is kept and subsequent occurrences removed.

inputs.in-1: default single input, name used as key in Map

help.helpText: Build a new Map from given inputs. Number of inputs is specified via module options (wrench icon). The names of input are used as map keys so make sure to change them!

inputs.listOrMap: list or map to collect from

help.helpText:
Given a list/map of maps, selects from each an entry according to parameter selector, and then returns a list/map of the collected entry values.

 

In case a map does not have an entry for selector, or the value is null, that entry will be simply skipped in the resulting output.

 

Map entry selector supports dot and array notation for selecting from nested maps and lists, e.g. "parents[1].name" would return ["Homer", "Fred"] for input [{name: "Bart", parents: [{name: "Marge"}, {name: "Homer"}]}, {name: "Pebbles", parents: [{name: "Wilma}, {name: "Fred"}]}]
This module allows you to enter a constant Map object, which is a set of key-value pairs. It can be connected to any Map input in Streamr - for example, to set headers on the HTTP module.
Determine whether a map contains a value.

params.sort: Whether key-count pairs should be order by count
params.maxKeyCount: Maximum number of (sorted) key-count pairs to keep. Everything else will be dropped.

outputs.valueOfCurrentKey: The occurrence count of the last key received.

help.helpText: Keeps count of the occurrences of keys.

params.keys: if empty, keep all entries. otherwise filter by given keys.

help.helpText: Filter incoming maps by retaining entries with specified keys.

params.canvas: The "sub" canvas that implements the ForEach-loop "body"

outputs.map: The state of outputs of all distinct Canvases by key.

help.helpText:
This module allows you to reuse a Canvas saved into the Archive as a module in your current Canvas.

A separate Canvas instance will be created for each distinct key, which enables ForEach-like behavior to be implemented. The canvas instances will also retain state as expected.

Any parameters, inputs or outputs you export will be visible on the module. You can export endpoints by right-clicking on them and selecting "Toggle export".

outputs.found: 1.0 if key was present in map, 0.0 otherwise.
outputs.out: the corresponding value if key was found.

help.helpText: Retrieve a value from a map by key.

outputs.founds: an array indicating for each output with 0 (false) and (1) whether a value was found
outputs.out-1: a (default) value from map, output name is used as key

help.helpText: Get multiple values from a Map.  The names of outputs are used as map keys so make sure to change them!

params.limit: the number of entries to fetch

outputs.out: a submap of the first entries of map

help.helpText: Retrieve first (n=limit) entries of a map.

params.limit: the number of entries to fetch

outputs.out: a submap of the first entries of map

help.helpText: Retrieve first (n=limit) entries of a map.
Determine the number of entries in a map.
Merge rightMap onto leftMap resulting in a single map. In case of conflicting keys, entries of rightMap will replace those of leftMap.

params.alwaysNew: When false (defult), same map is sent every time. When true, a new map is sent on each activation.

help.helpText: Emit a map everytime trigger receives a value.

outputs.map: a map with the key-value entry inserted

help.helpText: Put a key-value-entry into a map.

outputs.out: a map without the removed key

help.helpText: Remove an entry for a map by key.

params.byValue: when false (default), sorts by key. when true, sorts by value

help.helpText: Sorts a map.

params.windowLength: Limit moving window size of sum.
params.sort: Whether key-sum pairs should be order by sums
params.maxKeyCount: Maximum number of (sorted) key-sum pairs to keep. Everything else will be dropped.

inputs.value: The value to be added to aggregated sum.

outputs.valueOfCurrentKey: The aggregated sum of the last key received.

help.helpText: Keeps aggregated sums of received key-value-pairs by key.

params.limit: the number of entries to fetch

outputs.out: a submap of the last entries of map

help.helpText: Retrieve last (n=limit) entries of a map.
Retrieves the values of a map.

params.fields: the fields to be assigned to the stream

outputs.created: true if stream was created, false if failed to create stream
outputs.stream: the id of the created stream

help.helpText: Create a new stream.

params.fields: the fields to be assigned to the stream if a new stream is created

inputs.name: name of the stream
inputs.description: human-readable description if a new stream is created

outputs.created: true if stream was created, false if existing stream was found
outputs.stream: the id of the found or created stream

help.helpText: Find existing stream by name, or create a new stream if a stream by that name doesn't exist yet. If a stream is found, fields and description inputs are ignored.

inputs.name: stream to search for by name, must be exact

help.helpText: Search for a stream by name
Concatenates (appends) the given strings. For example if input A is "foo" and input B is "bar", the output is "foobar".
This module represents a constant text value that can be connected to any input that accepts text.
Tests whether the input string contains the substring given as the search parameter. If it does, 1 is sent out. Otherwise the output is 0.
Tests whether the input string ends with the substring given as the search parameter. If it does, 1 is sent out. Otherwise the output is 0.
Format a number into a string with a specified number of decimal places.

outputs.result: Map, List or value that the JSON string represents

help.helpText: JSON string should fulfill the JSON specification.

inputs.trigger: when value is received, activates module

help.helpText: Generate fixed-length random strings from an equiprobable symbol pool. Allowed symbols can be configured from module settings.

outputs.match?: 1 if in the text is something that matches with the pattern. Else 0.
outputs.matchCount: How many matches there are in the text.
outputs.matchList: A list of the matches. An empty list if there aren't any.

help.helpText: Module for analyzing text with a Regular Expression (Regex) pattern. Pattern is given in java format, without the starting and ending slashes.
Searches the input text by the search parameter, and if it is found, replaces it with the replaceWith parameter and outputs the result.

Splits the text by a given separator and outputs a list with the results

Examples:

  • Separator: " "(empty space),Text: "Two Words"
    • Output: Two, Words
Tests whether the input string starts with the substring given as the search parameter. If it does, 1 is sent out. Otherwise the output is 0.

inputs.args: Map of arguments that will be substituted into the template

help.helpText:
For template syntax, see StringTemplate cheatsheet.

Values of the args map are added as substitutions in the template. For example, incoming map {name: "Bernie", age: 50} substituted into template "Hi, <name>!" would produce string "Hi, Bernie!"

Nested maps can be accessed with dot notation: {name: "Bernie", pet: {species: "dog", age: 3}} substituted into "What a cute <pet.species>!" would result in "What a cute dog!".

Lists will be smashed together: {pals: ["Sam", "Herb", "Dud"]} substituted into "BFF: me, <pals>" results in "BFF: me, SamHerbDud". Separator must be explicitly given: "BFF: me, <pals; separator=", ">" gives "BFF: me, Sam, Herb, Dud".

Transforming list items can be done with { x | f(x) } syntax, e.g. {pals: ["Sam", "Herb", "Dud"]} substituted into "<pals: { x | Hey <x>! }> Hey y'all!" results in "Hey Sam! Hey Herb! Hey Dud! Hey y'all!".

outputs.error: Error if input can't be parsed

help.helpText:
Parse a number from the input string.

Examples of valid floating-point numbers:

  • "1"
  • "3.14159"
  • "-.234e4" (outputs -2340)
  • "+3.e1" (outputs 30)
Tests whether the input string equals with the string given as the search parameter. If it does, 1 is sent out. Otherwise the output is 0.
Ouputs the length of the input text (all characters including).
Outputs the input text in lower case.
Outputs the input text in upper case.

Removes the whitespace in front of and behind the input text.

E.g.  "         example with a space       " -> "example with a space"
Transforms the input value (which can be any value) into text.

outputs.date: String notation of the time and date

help.helpText:
Tells the time and date at fixed time intervals (by default every second). Outputs the time either in string notation of given format or as a timestamp (milliseconds from 1970-01-01 00:00:00.000).

The time interval can be chosen with parameter unit and granularly controlled via parameter rate. For example, unit=minute and rate=2 will tell the time every other minute.

params.format: Format of the input and output string notations

help.helpText:
Takes a date as an input in either in Date object, timestamp(ms) or in string notation. If the input is in text form, is the given format used.

Example:

Parameters:

  • Format <- "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss"
  • Timezone <- Europe/Helsinki


Inputs:

  • Date in <- "2015-07-15 13:06:13" or 1436954773474

Outputs: 

  • Date out -> 2015-07-15 13:06:13
  • ts -> 1436954773474
  • dayOfWeek -> "Wed"
  • years -> 2015
  • months -> 7
  • days -> 15
  • hours -> 13
  • minutes -> 6
  • seconds -> 13
  • milliseconds -> 0

outputs.value: The value from a active rule or the default value

help.helpText:
Outputs a certain value at a certain time. E.g. Every day from 10:00 to 14:00 the module outputs value 1 and otherwise value 0.
If more than one rule are active at the same time, the value from the rule with the highest priority (the highest rule in the list) is sent.
If no rule is active, the default value will be sent out.
Tells the time between two consecutive events in milliseconds.
Outputs 1 if the current time of day (in the time zone your user account is set to) is between startTime and endTime (both inclusive). At other times outputs 0.

inputs.trigger: any value; causes module to activate, i.e., produce output

help.helpText: Get timestamp for the event currently being processed. Similar to Clock, but instead of generating events, this module is triggered manually through input trigger.

This module implements a realtime maximal overlap discrete wavelet transform (MODWT). A number of different wavelets are available.

Note that, like all filters, the MODWT introduces increasing amounts of delay with higher levels of smoothing. No additional delay is added to any level - this means that a multi-level decomposition is not aligned at a given time. Reconstructing the original signal would require adding delay to all but the last level.

This module calculates the simple moving average (MA, SMA) of values arriving at the input. Each value is assigned equal weight. The moving average is calculated based on a sliding window of adjustable length.

params.minSamples: Minimum number of input values received before a value is output
params.length: Length of the sliding window, ie. the number of most recent input values to include in calculation

help.helpText:
Smooths the incoming time series by calculating an exponential moving average (EMA)

  • EMA(t) = a x in(t) + (1-a) x EMA(t-1)
  • a = \(2 \over \text{length} + 1\)
Evaluates an ARIMA prediction model with given parameters. Check the module options to set the number of autoregressive and moving average parameters. Model fitting is not (yet) implemented.

params.min: lower bound of interval to sample from
params.max: upper bound of interval to sample from

inputs.trigger: when value is received, activates module

help.helpText: Generate random numbers between [min, max] with uniform probability.

inputs.trigger: when value is received, activates module

help.helpText: Generate random numbers from normal (Gaussian) distribution with mean mean and standard deviation sd.

outputs.out: The absolute value of the original value

help.helpText: Outputs the absolute value (positive value with original sign stripped) of the input.
Adds together two or more numeric input values.
Outputs the difference between the received value and the previous received value, or in(t) - in(t-1).
Outputs the logarithmic difference (log return) between the received value and the previous received value, or log[in(t)] - log[in(t-1)].
Outputs the received value divided by the previous received value, or in(t) / in(t-1). If the previous received value is zero, the result is undefined and no output is produced.
Counts the number of incoming events.
This module calculates the quotient of its two input values. If the input B is zero, the result is not defined and thus no output is produced.

outputs.A/B: The quotient: A divided by B

outputs.error: error message if evaluation failed (e.g. syntax error in expression)

help.helpText:
Evaluate arbitrary mathematical expressions containing operators, variables, and functions. Variables introduced in an expression will automatically appear as inputs.

 

See https://github.com/uklimaschewski/EvalEx#supported-operators for further detail about supported features.
Outputs the multiplicative inverse (reciprocal) of the input (1/in, in^-1).

Linearly transforms a range of incoming (x) values to a range of outgoing (y) values. For example, this could be used to transform the input range of -1...1 (xMin...xMax) into an output range of 0...1000 (yMin...yMax).

Incoming values outside the x range will just output the min/max y value.
Outputs the natural logarithm of the input value.
Outputs the greater one of the two input values. For finding the maximum in a window of values, see the Max (window) module.
Outputs the lesser one of the two input values. For finding the minimum in a window of values, see the Min (window) module.

Calculates the remainder of two values. Outputs ( divisor mod divider).

E.g.

  • 3 mod 2 = 1

inputs.A: The first value to be multiplied
inputs.B: The second value to be multiplied

help.helpText: This module calculates the product of two numeric input values.
Outputs the negated input value -1 * in.
Rounds incoming values to given precision/step. The direction of rounding can be set with the mode parameter.
Outputs the sign of the input: -1 if the input is negative, 0 if the input is zero, and 1 if the input is positive.
Calculates the square root of the input.
This module calculates the difference of its two input values.
Calculates the (optionally rolling) sum of incoming values. For an infinite sum, enter a windowLength of 0.

params.minSamples: How many values must exist in the window before outputting a value
params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window of values to be summed, or 0 for infinite

outputs.out: Sum of values in the window

help.helpText: Calculates (Pearson's) correlation between two input variables in a sliding window of length windowLength.
Calculates the covariance of two input variables in a sliding window of length windowLength.
Calculates the geometric mean of incoming values in a sliding window of length windowLength. At least minSamples values must be received before an output is produced.

Calculates the kurtosis (or fourth standardized moment) of a distribution of values in a sliding window. Kurtosis is a measure of the "peakedness" of a distribution.

Note that at least 4 samples is required to calculate kurtosis.

params.minSamples: Number of samples required to produce output. At least 4 samples are required to calculate kurtosis
params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window of values

help.helpText: Calculates the maximum value in a sliding window of length windowLength. At least minSamples values must be received before an output is produced.
Calculates the minimum value in a sliding window of length windowLength. At least minSamples values must be received before an output is produced.
Calculates the value below which a given percentage of values fall in a sliding window of observations.

params.minSamples: Minimum number of observations for producing output
params.percentage: This percentage (0-100) of observations fall under the output of this module

outputs.out: The value under which percentage % of input values fall

help.helpText: Calculates the non-bias-corrected population variance. See the Variance module or bias-corrected variance.
Calculates the skewness (or third standardized moment) of a distribution of values in a sliding window. Skewness is a measure of the asymmetry of a distribution.

params.minSamples: Number of samples required to produce output
params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window of values

help.helpText: Calculates Spearman's Rank correlation between two input variables in a sliding window of length windowLength.
Calculates the standard deviation in a sliding window of the input time series.

params.minSamples: Minimum number of observations for producing output
params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window (number of observations)

help.helpText: Calculates the sum of squared input values in a sliding window of length windowLength. At least minSamples values are collected before producing output.
Performs a least-squares linear regression on a sliding window of input data. The model is y = slope*X + intercept.

params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window as number of samples

outputs.error: Mean square error (MSE) of the fit

help.helpText: Calculates the bias-corrected sample variance (with N-1 in the denominator). Use the PopulationVariance module for the non-bias-corrected population variance.

This is a utility for moving from event time to wall-clock time. This module outputs new values every barLength seconds. You would use this module to sample a time series every 60 seconds, for example.

params.barLength: Length of the bar (time interval) in seconds

outputs.avg: Simple average of values received during the period
outputs.close: Value at end of period (the most recent value)

help.helpText:
This module will delay the received values by a number of events. For example, if the delayEvents parameter is set to 1, the module will always output the previous value received.

The module will not produce output until the delayEvents+1th event, at which point the first received value will be output. For example, if the parameter is set to 2, the following sequence would be produced:

InputOutput
1(no value)
2(no value)
31
42
......

params.delayEvents: Number of events to delay the incoming values

inputs.value: Value to be sampled into the bar
inputs.valueLength: Length of each event, contributes to barLength

help.helpText:
Similar to the Barify module, which creates open-high-low-close bars equally long in time, this module creates bars equally long in an arbitrary variable passed into the valueLength input.

Incoming valueLength is summed for the current bar until barLength is reached, at which point the outputs are sent and the bar is reset.

Note that if multiple bars would be filled on the same event, only one is output. To avoid this situation you may want to keep barLength substantially larger than incoming valueLength.

params.barLength: Length of each bar (in valueLength units)

outputs.avg: Average of values received during the period, weighted by valueLength
outputs.close: Value at end of period (the most recent value)

help.helpText: This module just sends out whatever it receives.

This module waits for the input signal to reach either the highTrigger or lowTrigger level. Either 1 or -1 is output respectively. The triggered value is kept until it is set back to 0 at the corresponding release level.

If you set mode to exit, the output will trigger when exiting the trigger level instead of entering it.

params.mode: Trigger on entering/exiting the high/low trigger level

outputs.out: 1 on high trigger, -1 on low trigger, 0 on release

help.helpText:
Attempts to detect upward turns below lowZone (outputs 1) and downward turns below highZone (outputs -1).

For an upward turn to be registered, the change between subsequent input values must be larger than threshold. For a downward turn the change must be less than -threshold.

params.highZone: The level above which a downward turn can occur
params.lowZone: The level below which an upward turn can occur
params.threshold: The minimum change in the correct direction between subsequent input values that is allowed to trigger a turn

outputs.out: 1 for upward turn and -1 for downward turn

help.helpText:
This module can be used to sample values from one timeseries upon events from another timeseries, just like the Sampler module.

However the triggerIf value must be equal to 1 for the value at value input to be sent out. Trigger events with other values than 1 will produce no effect.

This module can be used to sample values from one timeseries upon events from another timeseries.

An event arriving at the trigger input will cause the module to send out whatever value the value input has. The trigger is the only driving input.
This module outputs -1, 0 or +1 depending on whether the input value is below lowZone, between lowZone and highZone, or above highZone respectively.

outputs.out: -1, 0 or +1 depending on which zone the input value is in

help.helpText: This module is used to detect when a time series crosses the zero line. It outputs -1 when below zero (minus threshold) and +1 when above zero (plus threshold).

params.strictMode: In strict mode, the incoming series actually needs to cross the trigger line before an output is produced. Otherwise a value is produced on the first event above or below the trigger line.
params.threshold: Zero or a positive value indicating the distance beyond zero that the incoming series must reach before a different output is triggered

help.helpText:
This module allows you to reuse a Canvas saved into the Archive as a module in your current Canvas. This enables reuse and abstraction of functionality and helps keep your Canvases tidy and modular.

Any parameters, inputs or outputs you export will be visible on the module. You can export endpoints by right-clicking on them and selecting "Toggle export".
Just a text box for comments. Commenting what you build is a good idea, as it helps you and others understand what is going on.
This module represents a constant numeric value that can be connected to any numeric input. The input will have that value during the whole execution.

params.subject: Email Subject
params.message: Custom message to include in the email, optional

help.helpText:
The Email module can be used to send notifications to your email address. Just like any module, it activates when an event is received at any driving input. The number of inputs can be set in module options, and the values at the inputs will be included in the email content. The inputs can be renamed to give them more descriptive names.

When running against historical data, emails are not actually sent. Instead, a notification is shown representing the would-be email. Emails are capped at one per minute to avoid accidental self-spamming.

Here's an example of email content:

Message:
(your custom message)

Event Timestamp:
2014-11-18 10:30:00.124

Input Values:
value1: 7357
value2: test value

Generates a CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file from event data that flows into this modules inputs. The file download link becomes available once the canvas has been started, and then stopped. You may wish to connect the inputs of this module to a `stream` module with real-time data flowing.

inputs.pass: The filter condition. 1 (true) for letting the event pass, 0 (false) to filter it out

outputs.out: The event that came in, if passed. If filtered, nothing is sent

help.helpText: Only lets the incoming value through if the value at pass is 1. If this condition is not met, no event is sent out.
Displays a text representation of the input received in real-time. This module can take any data type and is often used to debug your canvas or display a single piece of data.
Display contents of a list as a table. If it's a list of maps, break maps into columns
Display the entries of a map as a table.

Merges two event streams into one. Whatever arrives at inputs A or B is sent out from the single output. The inputs and the output can be connected to all types of endpoints. A runtime error may occur if there is a type conflict.

params.windowLength: Length of the sliding window, ie. the number of most recent input values to include in calculation
params.minSamples: Minimum number of input values received before a value is output

outputs.list: the window's current state as a list

help.helpText: Provides a moving window (list) for any types of values. Window size and behavior can be set via parameters.

params.rate: How many messages are let through in given time
params.timeInMillis: The time in milliseconds, in which the given number of messages are let through

outputs.limitExceeded?: Outputs 1 if the message was blocked and 0 if it wasn't
outputs.out: Outputs the input value if it wasn't blocked

help.helpText: The RateLimit module lets through n messages in t milliseconds. Then module just blocks the rest which do not fit in the window.

Simply passes the values of inputs to corresponding outputs, but only if all inputs receive a value on the same event. If one or more inputs do not receive a value on an event, none of the values are sent forward.

Capable of pushing data from your canvas into a selected stream. The module will reveal its inputs based on the fields configured on your selected stream. To select your stream click into the value input inside the module and select from the dropdown menu containing all the streams you have permission to access. Ensure that your selected stream has some fields configured, otherwise the module will not show any inputs.

Displays a table of events arriving at the inputs along with their timestamps. The number of inputs can be adjusted in module options. Every input corresponds to a table column. Very useful for debugging and inspecting values. The inputs can be connected to all types of outputs.
This module represents a constant color value, that can be connected to any color input. The input will have that value during the whole execution.

Generates an RGBA color string based on the combination of its inputs. The `Min Value` input correlates to the `Min Color` input. The `Max Value` input correlates to the `Max Color` input. The color output is determined by the `in` input in relation to these boundary values. For example, `Min Value = 0` `In = 0` `Min Color = Output Color` (e.g. White) Where, `Max Value = 1` `In = 1` `Max Color = Output Color` (e.g. Black) Where, `In = 0.5` Output color will be grey (rgba(128,128,128,1))

This module is the main tool for visualizing time series. The chart is updated on fly as new data becomes available. You can zoom the chart by dragging over the area you want to zoom to. To pan the chart while zoomed, use the navigator below the chart. Individual series can be toggled on or off by clicking on the series name in the legend. Also note that the chart module can be resized by dragging from its lower right corner.

Each input series is drawn on y-axis 1 by default. You can edit y-axis assignments by clicking the button beside the input endpoint.

The number of inputs is adjustable in the module options (the wrench icon). Other options include ignoring data points outside a certain time of day.

The module can also produce a downloadable CSV file containing whatever data points are sent to the chart. To use this feature, run in CSV export mode by selecting that option from the Run button dropdown menu.
Displays a colored heatmap overlay on top of a geographical map.

inputs.id: Id of the marker to place. Will also be displayed on hover over the marker.

help.helpText:
This module displays a world map. Markers can be drawn on the map at WGS84 coordinates given to the inputs latitude and longitude as decimal numbers (degrees). Markers also have an id. To draw multiple markers, connect the id input. Coordinates for the same id will move the marker, and coordinates for a new id will create a new marker.

In module options, you can enable directional markers to expose an additional heading input, which controls marker heading (e.g. vehicles on the street or ships at sea). Other options include marker coloring, autozoom behavior etc.

inputs.id: Id of the marker to draw
inputs.x: Horizontal coordinate of the marker between 0 and 1
inputs.y: Vertical coordinate of the marker between 0 and 1

help.helpText:
This module displays a map based on an user-defined image. The image is loaded from a URL given in module options. The map automatically scales x and y coordinates between 0..1 to image dimensions. This means that regardless of image size in pixels (x,y) = (0,0) is the top left corner of the image, and (1,1) is the bottom right corner.

Markers also have an id. To draw multiple markers, connect the id input. Coordinates for the same id will move the marker, and coordinates for a new id will create a new marker.

In module options, you can enable directional markers to expose an additional heading input, which controls marker heading (e.g. direction in which people are facing in a space). Other options include marker coloring, autozoom behavior etc.
